docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama warned the nation's governors Monday that a looming shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security would have a direct impact on their states' economies, as well as on security throughout the U.S.

headline.main: Obama to Governors: DHS Shutdown Would Hurt State Economies
headline.print_headline: Obama to Governors: DHS Shutdown Would Hurt State Economies

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama warned the nation's governors Monday that a looming shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security would have a direct impact on their states' economies, as well as on security throughout the U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about Monday:
docs.snippet: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about Monday:

docs.lead_paragraph: Union members ratified an agreement on Sunday that ends a four-month-long strike by some 1,800 workers at FairPoint Communications, a major land-line telecommunications provider in northern New England, union officials announced.

headline.main: Telecom Workers Ratify Agreement to End Strike in New England
headline.print_headline: Telecom Workers Ratify Agreement to End Strike in New England

docs.snippet: Union members ratified an agreement on Sunday that ends a four-month-long strike by some 1,800 workers at FairPoint Communications, a major land-line telecommunications provider in northern New England, union officials announced.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of people could lose health insurance subsidies in the coming months if the Supreme Court sides with opponents of President Barack Obama's health care overhaul.

headline.main: Governors: No Clear Plan if Health Care Subsidies Fall
headline.print_headline: Governors: No Clear Plan if Health Care Subsidies Fall

docs.lead_paragraph: The agency created five decades ago to fight poverty in Appalachia has helped county economies grow with nearly $4 billion in spending, but the region still lags in key measures of educational, economic and physical well-being, according to a new study.

headline.main: Appalachia Report Cites Progress, Challenges After 50 Years
headline.print_headline: Appalachia Report Cites Progress, Challenges After 50 Years

docs.lead_paragraph: FairPoint Communications workers ratified a new contract during three days of voting, ending a four-month strike by more than 1,700 workers in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, two unions announced Sunday.

headline.main: Striking FairPoint Workers Ratify Tentative Agreement
headline.print_headline: Striking FairPoint Workers Ratify Tentative Agreement

docs.snippet: FairPoint Communications workers ratified a new contract during three days of voting, ending a four-month strike by more than 1,700 workers in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, two unions announced Sunday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amicus curiae, or friend of the court, briefs are flooding into the Supreme Court ahead of oral arguments March 4 that could determine the fate of the health care law.

headline.main: Flood of Briefs on the Health Care Law’s Subsidies Hits the Supreme Court
headline.print_headline: Flood of Briefs on the Health Care Law’s Subsidies Hits the Supreme Court

docs.abstract: Conservatives and liberal Democrats alike are flooding Supreme Court with friend of the court legal briefs ahead of oral arguments in case King v Burwell, which is challenging payment of subsidies for health insurance in over 30 states in effort to overturn health care law; experts say briefs, which judges read carefully and may rely on, could influence outcome of case.
docs.snippet: Amicus curiae, or friend of the court, briefs are flooding into the Supreme Court ahead of oral arguments March 4 that could determine the fate of the health care law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Which candidates are true reformers, and which are just giving reform lip service?
docs.abstract: Ross Douthat Op-Ed column suggests that best test for Republican presidential candidate to distinguish himself from rest of field is by proposals for taxes and health care; notes it is not coincidental that policy test is one Republicans have repeatedly failed during Pres Obama's tenure.
docs.snippet: Which candidates are true reformers, and which are just giving reform lip service?

docs.lead_paragraph: In its second year, Obamacare is proving to be a success. From Feb. 22, 2015.

headline.main: For Tens of Millions, Obamacare Is Working

docs.snippet: In its second year, Obamacare is proving to be a success. From Feb. 22, 2015.

docs.lead_paragraph: To detect possible abuse of programs or benefits, state and local governments are turning to data-mining techniques long used by financial services companies.

headline.main: Bringing Big Data to the Fight Against Benefits Fraud
headline.print_headline: Connecting the Dots to Spot Benefits Fraud

docs.abstract: Natasha Singer Technophoria column observes that state and local agencies are turning to data-mining services to root out public benefits fraud; notes that governments are using services provided by IBM, SAS and LexisNexis to uncover fraud in unemployment insurance, Medicaid, food stamps and several other programs.
docs.snippet: To detect possible abuse of programs or benefits, state and local governments are turning to data-mining techniques long used by financial services companies.
